comments:
The mac launcher has been prepended jdi.jar to the bootclasspath when launching eclipse because 
apple packages their jdi implementation in classes.jar instead of a separate tools.jar and apple's JDI 
implementation was being found instead of our own. 
Jarring the plugin means that jdi.jar classes now live in org.eclipse.jdt.debug_3.1.0.jar. Prepending the 
entire plugin to the bootclasspath causes the following exception: 

org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Exception in

Reverted to un-jar'd format for org.eclipse.jdt.debug.

Andre, since we've unjarred, we'll need to change the launcher back to 
-Xbootclasspath/p:../../../plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.debug_3.1.0/jdi.jar

verified
(Thanks Andre, sorry about the extra work)

For the record, the technique of -Xbootpath../../.. etc. is very brittle.  It 
means that the debug plugin can never be updated without having to have some 
manual step of updating the file that contains the directive.

I don't have a particular solution at hand.  There is some function in the OSGi 
spec for this but it is optional ( we are not implementing for 3.1) and very 
specific.

For now I suggest that JDI should be packaged as its own plugin (or even a 
fragment).  This means the JDI code would be alone in a JAR so the boot path 
trick would work and it will be on the jdt.debug plugin classpath as normal.

What package are the jdi classes in?  Jeff, if we make the move to only 
delegate java.* packages to the boot classloader then would is solve this 
problem?  If the jdi classes are not in a java.* package then the bundles in 
eclipse would only get access to the jdi classes provided in the 
org.eclipse.jdt.debug bundle, right?
JDI classes are in com.sun.jdi.* packages.

the problem here is that on the Mac, we need our JDI classes to override the 
ones included in the Mac VM's system (not boot) classloader.  So they have to 
go on the boot loader on the Mac.

Re: comment 9

I'm not sure I understand the difference between the Mac VM's system (not 
boot) classloader and the regular old boot classloader on other platforms.

Currently we delegate all class loads to the parent classloader (boot 
classloader).  It is possible to not delegate all classloads to the parent.  
If this is done then it would allow the com.sun.jdi.* packages to be loaded 
from the debug bundle instead the Mac VM's system (not boot) classloader, 
right?

I'm not suggesting this is the best fix but it seems like this scenario is one 
of the motivations behind not delegating all class loads to the parent.  It 
allows for bundles to override what is available in the boot classpath.

problem as I understand it is at a differnet level.  The Mac JRE has a version 
of the JDI classes on the system classpath.  They are the wrong level.  We need 
more recent ones.  To get them there they have to be on the bootpath.

Other VMs dont have this problem because they don't include JDI this way.

Jeff is correct
Apple has basically combined tools.jar and rt.jar, called it classes.jar and put it on the system classpath. 
Means that we can't substitute our JDI implementation for theirs w/o prepending ours to the bootpath.
I filed a radar bug against this and tried to raise Apple's awareness about this problematic issue.
